div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,141] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, MARCH 7, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Pagnon's Hotels
div.p: Cataract Hotel, Assounan

This most popular hotel on the Upper Nile has recently been enlarged by the addition of 65 rooms and accomodates 360 guests. Grand dining hall, life, tennis court, and garden. On the south side overlooking the river. Billard room and bar., Electric light throughout. Anglican Church within a few minutes of the Hotel grounds.

Grand Hotel Assouan.- Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Accomodates 80 guests. Moderate terms. Entirely rebuilt since the fire, and fitted throughout in the most modern style. Beautiful Terrance overlooking river. Electric lights throughout.

div.head: Grand Hotel, Khartoum
div.p: Standing in a magnificent position in its own grounds on the high banks of the Blue Nile.
Elegantly Furnished: Every comfort and convenience; through connection with London; perfect climate; lovely gardens; excellent cuisine - Wire Manager, Hotel, Khartoum.

div.head: Grand Hotel Helouan.
div.p: Finest and most luxurious Hotel near Cairo. Patronized by Royalty. Moderate Charges.- Special terms for residents. Golf Links (18 Holes) with English Professional. Own Golf House in the desert.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN CRISIS.
div.p: As banal, there are two sitnations in
Russian affairs to be watched with the closest
interest, the sitnation at home and the situa-
tion at the front Both have now become
just about as bad as they could possibly
be, and our interest has beonme positively
morbid. To watch the telegraph for the nut
news from St Petersburg, the provinces, or
Manohuria, gives something of the sensation
produced by watching an acrobat in a
national performance. But whereas we
pretty sure, ninety-nine timed out of a 1
dred, that the acrobat will not oome to u
we are equally sure that Russia must I
a grievous fall. Aid there is no net
break its force. Unless appearauoes are tot
deceptive, Kuropatkin and his army ai
tke most awkward position, and in fact
of this morning's telegrams goes so far a
declare that "the escape of thq Run
main force seams impossible.”
If the “formidable force of Japanese,” wl
it is feared, "is en route for Tieling,” ate.
its goal before the oomplete evacuatiui
Mukden, the position of General Kuropa
must be perilous in the extreme, and
heavy fighting to.the north west of Aiul
shows that the Russian retreat is iu dang;
being cut off. A telegram states that ‘a cm
expected on Monday or Tuesday,” but whe
this refers to the entire Russian Army we
not say. At any rate everything lends to s
(Hat the Russian defeat will iu a few In
become a disastrous rout, and it is not U
any attempt will be made to hold Mukden
efforts being concentrated on a desperate «t
at Tieling. The prospect does notseem aba
one for the Russiaus. Once disastrously ou
run, there is no reason to suppose that 1
, would do better at Tieling than elsewhere,
! we have yet to learn the exact whereabo
strength, and movements of the myster
force which has already got behiud the Kus
retreat, and may be astride the railway
tween Mukden and Tieling. In the autum
; was Sedan that was on our lips and in
minds. To-day it is Moscow. Even suppo
( that all was well in the camp, Kuropatl
danger would be great But if a tube of
rumours have - a foundation of fact, bis arm
neither in the mood nor the condition to t
such a fight as is belore it Ttie uieu, we 1
been told, are dispirited, mutinous, and I
starved. The officers, we know, are at sixes
sevens. No doubt Japan is hitting hard in i
of the possible arrangement of terms of pe
And it looks as if this latest battle m
modify considerably the» terms that Ku
might now obtain from a victorious enemy
Of oonrse the situation at the front and
situation at home are interdependent,
military position has been made more pi
rious and impossible by the insurrection wl
is now general, throughout Russia. Althc
the censor is still at work, aud we have
mere scraps of news sinoe Vladimir’s da}
Petersburg, the most pessimistic- of our I
casts are in the way of realisation. Short
a declared revolution things oould hardly
worse. Anarchy is rampaub Bailway <
munication has oeased on most lines.
Government are at their wit’s end, and
only advise local authorities to "do the
they can." ’Troops cannot be spared even
quell disturbances in the provinces. M
less oould they be spared to reinfi
Kuropatkin, even if they were in a n
for Manchurian fighting, aud even if tl
was any Mssibility—which there is not -
oonveyin \ them to the front The result
Russia ibeli aud the Russian Governmer
unoertaih. Out of the welter of chaos s<
new order aud system may emerge in ti
though imagination boggles at the probt
history of the intervening period. The re
for Kuropatfrin and his army is sure. Star
of supplies, oi men, of food, aud ammuuit
he finds himself isolated, out off from
distant base, thrown ou such resources as
country affords, and compelled to give ba
with dispirited troops and quarrelsome offi
to an enemy superior in numbers, equipnn
valour, and skill. It is not by the reoul
this battle or this campaign that his -niiiii
geuius can ever be truly judged.
Whether by the Tsar’s ownact or that of
people we may surely expect Russia to n
peace before long. There will be no other co<
open toher. Even were ourfriendRojdestvet
to sweep Togo from the sea—if—the use
reason of a naval viotory would be almost
troyed by the failure of the land cam]>s
Aud the "if’ is a singularly big one. Ha'
committed all the lollies — not forgetting
Dogger fight—that lunacy oould cram into
year of crowded life, the Russian Govern®
will be forced to oonclude such a peace as
pan may allow them. It will probably be «
another defeat and once more action will t
been takan several days too late. As with
ooncession of demands, so with the releav
Gorki, and so with the oonduct of the c
paign. Stupid blunders are made. No puq
is served by them, and the remedy com#
late. There is only one hope left for
friends of Russia—and we are not her fix
that the last tragedy of all may be avei
before the opportunity for that saving da
has gone with the rest,

Mariout Causeway.— Owing to the increas­ing develop went of the Mariout district^ tht Causeway separating Lake Marootis from the salt lake, which is the only possible highway between Alexandria and Mariout, has become much too narrow for the traffic. Moreover, owing to the broadening of the railway gauge, there is very little space' even for a foot pas icuger. At this time of the year, wheu the dowers in the Manout district are in theii oeauty, many persons would like to ride ou! there, but in the present condition of tbe causeway it is dangerous, as one never knowt when a train carrying railway material'will appear on the causeway. The Publio Workt Department ought to undertake the broadening of this causeway in the interests both of the | Khedive and of tbe public .

div.head: STRANDING OF THE “CAlRO."
div.p: NOTHING SAVED FROM VESSEL.

The inquiry into the circuinsUnoes attend­ing the straudiug of the Florio-Rubattino 8J3. “Cairo,” which is being held at the Italian Consulate at Alexandria, is oonfined to deter­mining the responsibility for the catastrophe. The enquiry will be concluded to-morrow or the day after. Captain De Marchi has sent in his report

M. Novelli, the Italian tragedian, who was to have appeared at the Zizinia last night, has brought an action in the Italian Consular Court against the Florio-Rubattino Steam Navigation Company for tbe loss occasioned him. Ha. is asking for 300,000 francs compensation. The great actor’s dlecta were not insured.
Nothing has as yet been recovered from the vessel except a few effects, which have been cast into the sea by the foroe of the waves breaking over tbe steamer, and some of the mail bags.

We understand, that the Captain alleges that he is not responsible. He noticed a craft when drawing near the Boghaz Pass very like the pilot’s boat, and be made for it after having’ signalled, fully believing that it contained the pilot. When he was olose up to it ho reoogniaed that it was not the pilot's boat and then turn­ed the ship's head round.

Immediate rue lsurea have been taken by the General Pint Office in order to save as much as possible of the* mails carried by the S.8. “Cairo.” As, however, these mails have been greatly damaged by sea water, the Post Office will do its utmost to dry and deliver them by to-day.

div.head: A CAIRO NUISANCE.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes : — Cannot something be said or done to abate the great­est nuisance and offence of Cairo, the donkey- boys to wit 1 The shoeblacks, match-sellers, and others are improving daily ; we are no louger pestered except by isolated specimens; and those have the excuse of extreme youth and its consequent impishness. But your donkey boy‘is a real plague. He is usually an "adult," of a very low class, and up Jo the eyes steeped in vice ; that we all know, we need not enlarge thereon. Happily one does not need to pause and hear what “induce­ments” he has to offer for one’s patronage : but he should surely be absolutely forbidden (as is now largely the case at Meoa House) to accost or speak to people l for in this he is our "béte noire." It is impossible to walk quietly past a group of donkey-boys without “Coming, sarr, nioe donkey, sarr,” and much more howled at one, or to stop a moment without excitibga general charge. No reproof has any effebt un­less it be to bring a flow of filthy language. I speak for the residents more than tor visitors. We may not hit.them (they knowthatl) and we most of us cannot waste our time by calling the attention of the nearest policeman. They (the boys) know perfectly well who is resident and who is not, aud I am certain they take a pleasure iu annoying us. Besides, the tone of voice—as if they had been our trusted guides since infancy in every kind of vioe—is an insult How often has it not infariated me when walking peacefully along the streets 1 As if I wanted to ride a donkey, or as if I hadn’t a tongue in my head, or a pair of eyes, to speak and choose for myself as I would a cab. I appeal to the authorities : it would be so easy to give a general order that none ol these people are to acoost passers ; they are all numbered, all have their regular stands aud ranks. Almost always a "shawish” is somewhere within reach ; and if one or two examples were made, we should soon find the Cairo streets peaceful.

div.head: Notes from Port Said
Interesting Passangers
div.p: INTERESTING PASSENGERS.
(From Our Correspondent)

A further number of Russian officers and men, 57 of them in all, from Port Arthur, arrived at Port Said this morning by the P and O. S.S. "Britannia". Nearly all transhipped to the russian local steamer "Cearevitch" and will leave to-day for Odessa, via Alexandria. A few have been elected to proceed to Marseilles by the "Britannia".
The Portuguese cruiser "Vasco de Gama" (Capt. Emanuel), 249 crew and 14 guns arrived at Port Said on Friday afternoon from Hong Kong and leave to-day for Lisbon.

The Gernman Cruiser "Herths" (Capt. Feiherr von Sehimmelmann), 480 Crew and 34 guns arrived at Port Said this morning from Aden with Prince Adelbert on board. After coaling she will leave for the Piremps.

Prince Frederick Leopold of Prussia, Millitary Attaché to japan, was a passanger by the North German Lloyd steamer "Prinz Eitel Frederick", which arrived at Port Said early this afternoon. The port saluted the Imperial German Standard flying on the foremast. Prince frederick Leopold visted prince adelbert on the cruiser "Hertha" and also H. E. the Governor of the Suez Canal, Mustapha Ibadi Pasha.

div.head: Personal and Social
div.p: Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan left for Cairo yesterday afternoon.
Lord Cromer was among the guests at the banquet given at Abdeen Palace last night in honor of Major- General Slade, C.B.

H.I. and R.M. the Emperor King of Austria-Hungary has been pleased to confer the order of Francis Joseph (Commander with plague) on H.E. Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria. M. de Puscariu, Austro-Hungarian Consul, this morning handed his Excelency the brevet and insignia of the Order at the Gouvernorat.
Mgr. Sabak Aradian, Armenian Bishop of Persia and the Indies paid a visit to H.E. the Governor this morning.
Mr. Mitchell Innes, Under Secretary of Staet at the Ministry of Finance is going on leave towards the end of the month.

A marriage has been arranged between Horace Montague Rumbold, second secretary at the Brirish Agency, Cafro, eldest son of the Right Hon. Sir Horace Rumbold, Bart, G.C.B. G.C.M.G., and Etheldred Constantia, second daughter of the late sir Edmund Fane, K.C.M.G. and Lay Fane of Boyton, Wilts.

A delightful "At Home" was given yesterday afternoon by mrs. Perceval Foster at her residence in the Greek quarter, Alexandria. The whole of fashionable society at Alexandria was represented. A charming musical programme was provided for the guests.
Bimbashi Paxton, Inspector of the Cairo City Police, has obtained leav from the 16th March to the 30th June.

Mr. Christopher R. Nugent, the genial manager of the Union Discount Company, Limited, of London, is returning home via Italy, and is leaving on WEdnesday by the North German Lloyd steamer "Schleswig."

Shepheard's Restaurant is so crowded every night now that it is almost impossible to obtain a table if not orderd a day beforehand. Last saturday night, amongst many others dining the, we noticed M. div.head: Chronique Judiciare
Cour D;Appel Mixte
La Photographie
div.p: MM. Fix et David avaient fait opérer en Allemagne des reproductions et des réductions d’un grand nombre de photographies de divers paysages et types, égyptien^, propriété de M.

— photographe de profession qui eu fait le commerce — pour les appliquer à dos cartes postales, que les intimés vendent à Port- Saïd môme, où l'appelant exerce sa profession et son commerce. Dans ' quelques-unes de ces reproductions photographiques, le nom du photographe “Zaugakis" est encore visible.

Dans le jugement dont appel les premiers juges, tout en constatant l'existence de la con­trefaçon, déclarent néanmoins que les épreuves . que l’appelant avait produites ne pèuvent être considérées comme une œuvre d'art et ne sont qu'une série de clichés d’uné absolue banalité, sans aucun cachet personnel; que, d’autre part, la carte postale illustrée ne peut constituer une contrefaçon de la photographie, ni la vente da ces cartes postales une concurrence et sur­tout une couourrence déloyale, puisque la pho­tographie et la carte poatalo illustrée s’adres­sent à des amateurs différents, et ne peuvent servir aux mêmes usages.

La Cour vient d'infirmer ce jugement. Elle fait défense à l’iqtimé de reproduire sur cartes ]k»taies des photographies, propriété de l’ap­pelant, sans l’autorisation de celui-ci ; elle le condamne en outré aux frais des 2 instances et à payer à l'appelant, à titre de dommages- intérêts, la somme de £ 10.

“ Attendu, dit l’arrêt, que plusieurs légis lations accordent spécialement aux photogra­phies la même protection généralement ac­cordée aux œuvres d’art, sous certaines condi­tions et limitation de temps.

“ Que l’art. 1er de cette dernière loi pose nettement le principe que celui qui tire pour sou compte une image photographique origiunle d’après nature ou exécute une reproduction photographique d’une œuvre d’art dont la re­production est libre, a le droit exclusif de la copier par la photographie pour la vendre.

' “ Attendu qüo les conventions passées entre la France et la Belgique, la Suisse et l’Italie comprennent les photographies parmi les œuvres qui ont droit à la protection contre la repro­duction non autorisée. .

“ Attendu qu’en l’absence d’une loi spéciale surla propriété littéraire e^artistiqueen Egypte, cette propriété se trouVe par application de l’art. 34 du R.O.J., placée sous la sauvegarde du droit naturel et de l’équité, puisqu’il est de principe en droit, que toute atteinte portée à la propriété d’autrui donne lieu à une action contre celui qui eu est l’auteur.
“ Que la reproduction photographique d’une œuvre conçue et créée par un artiste constitue une concurrence déloyale qui est interdite.

" Qu’une photographie, quaud même elle ne puisse être considérée comme une œuvre artis­tique, ce qui, parfois, est une question d’ap­préciation, peut représenter toutefois une som­me considérable de frais, de peines et de soins, dont U ne serait pas juste qu’un autre que le photographe lui-même s’approprie pour spé­culer ;

“ Que peu importe si les choses représentées peuvent être reproduites par la photographie par tout le monde. Quo sans aucun doute, l’intimé était parfaitement libre d’aller prendre lee mêmes vues photographiques, et de foire ainsi une œuvre identique à celle de l’appelant, mais il aurait à foire les mêmes fiais et à sup­porter les mêmes fatigues ;

“ Attendu que si, en principe, l’appelant a le droit d’actionner l’intimé en dommages- intérêts, quant au montant de ces dommages- intérêts, il y a lieu de oonsidérer que la dimi­nution du commerce de l’appelant ne peut avoir pour cause principale la reproduction de ses photographies, mais quelle doit être fatale­ment le résultat do l’introduction dans le com­merce des cartes postales illustrées, lesquelles par leur bon marché, leur facile expédition et la place qu’elles occupent à présent dans la correspondance postale, font une concurrence extraordinaire aux collections de photographies en grand format ;

“ Qa’ainsi la production des livres de l’ap­pelant ainsi que de ceux de l’intimé, le seul moyen proposé pour la vérification da préju dice dont le même appelant se plaint, ne saurait être admise, comme ne pouvant pas fournir les indications nécessaires pour l’éva­luation des dom mages ;
" Que d’autre part la demande tout à fait fantaisiste de 2,000 £ de dommages-intérêts, ne prouve rien sinon que l’appelant a voulu ré­pondre ptf une spéculation à une spécula tion • * «
La Cour) se, basant sur le prix qne deman­dent les photographes les plus connus d’Egypte pour la reprodaotion de leurs photographies,

“ estime qu’en validant la saisie conserva­toire des qprtes postales faites par voie d’huisv. sier, en ordonnant la destruction des cartes postales saisies et en allouant à l’appelant la somme de 10 £, comme dommages-intérêts, pour la reproduction non autorisée des photo- graphies produites, elle aooorde à l’appelant une juste réparation. "
Conseil des Ministres
Le consceil des ministres, qni s’est rénni hier au palais d’Abdin, sous la présidence de S.A. le Khédive, a pris les décisions suivantes :
1. Sont nommés :
Moudir d’Awiout : Hassan Wassif bey, moudir de Charkieh, en remplacement de Mo- 1 hamed Zobri pacha, mis à la retraite.
Uoudir de Charkieh : Mohamed Moheb bey,
moudir de Fayonm

Moudir de Fayoum : Mohamed Ali Chanra bey, sous-moudir de Menoufieh. II. Sont nommés : Sous-moudir de Menoufieh : Mohamed Ali bey, sous-moudir de Keneh, en remplacement de Mohamed Ali Charara bey, appelé à d’antres fonctions. Sous-moudir de Keneh : Abdel Halim Na- ched effendi, mamour du district de Tonkh (Galioubieh). III. Sont déolarés d’utilité publique les travaux d’élargissement du canal Ibrahimieh à partir du Pont-Régulateur de Sharahnah jusqu’au pont du chemin de fer établi sur le oanal Maghnuna. IV. Est abrogé le décret du 23 août 1904, modifiant l’art 2 du décret du 20 juin 1904, concernant le prolongement du oanal El Gfai- lassi jusqu'au khor de Keneh, et la construction d’une digue sur le côté est dudit prolongement

div.head: A Tale of Médiévale Egypt
div.p: The title of this spirited historical romance, in which a Coptic love story is skilfully inter­woven with the unfortunate experiences of the St. Louis during the Sixth Crusade, carries us back, in thought, to the days of Cœur de Lion and Salih ed Din some six'y years Indore, and to their mutual admiration tor deeds of valour and noble generosity, so graphically described iu the pages of “Ivanhoe.” Hi'li ard's grandson, too, our own Edward I., tallowed closely on the track of the saintly En ... a few years later, when the latter found In? grave on the Tunisian shore. The site of the piesont story would, surely, be visited with much interest by the Anglo-American tourist who makes this couutry the goal of his r her winter pilgrimage, were it not that the -brine at which they worship iu the gay salons o! its attractive Capital better fulfils the luxurious requirements of the fair-skinned pilgrim of modern days than the Oriental Khans to be found in the present representative o! the ancient city of Damiàthis. The holy banner of the monk of St. Denis—the West­minster Abbey of the French nation—vanished with the battle of Agiucourt, nor are its origin and primary form accurately known ; but, as Wiriie in the Sixth Crusade, it seems to have been a square flag of crimson material attached to a gilt stall', its fly ending in three long points having tassels of green silk between them. Whether the points were co­loured with gold to resemble tongues, or flames of tire, or were only of wavy form to give the same effect, is uncertain. Du Cange held the latter view. Hut the almost contemporary description by Guillaume le Breton, historical poet and chaplain to Philip Augustus from I'.’ik) a.i>. to 1227 A.U., in the eleveuth book of Ids "Philippicus,"' seems to point to the former.
"Veillum simplex sandaco semplice textum Splendoris rubei.
(jpod cum tlamma habeat vulgariter aurea uotnW

Omnibus in bellis habet omnia signa praire.” When the late Canon Davis speaks of this llag as the “Royal {Standard,” at p. 25 of his “Invasion of Egypt,” he should rather say, the “War Standard of the Church,” as the royal colours—blue powdered with ‘fleur do lys —and the national colours—a white cross ou a blue grouud—were both contempora­neously in use on the battlefield. The holder of the sacred office of “Bearer of the Oriflam­me,” which latter was credited with the power of blinding the heretical enemy who looked upon it, and indicated that no quarter would be given or expected, was put through an elaliorate religious ceremonial at St Denis, •and received a final blessing before being entrusted with his precious charge, which led the way in the crusading battles and taught the faint-hearted soldier who had douned the Papal badge of St. George’s Cross, what he might expect, should a want of courage on his part lead to disaster. The church attribut­ed the disappearance of this flag to its use against Christian Powers. “Bed demumabut- teutibus regibus hoc signo advenus Chris ticolas evanuit,” ti&ya a historian early in the 17th century.

The present story opens with a miracle play .a the village of Lacock in Wiltshire, where the remains of the convent built in 1232 a.d. by Ella. Countess of Salisbury, who became its d)be*a a few yean later, are still inhabited.

the personification of the sacred cha- play is well portrayed and, no • approach to accuracy; during we are introduced to Hilary youthful hero of the lovestory.who, -.ier openly expressing his contempt, in the presence of the Papal Archdeacon, for the su­perstitious mummeries of the “dramatis per­sona;," euds by rescuing his "baby sweet­heart,” little Nell Denis, from the terrifying embrace of a hideous, horned, and tailed demon of the nether world ; thereby causing Humnlf to be placed by the offended priest in durance vile, until a severe scourging should be inflicted. Happily for him, bis friend, Matthew Paris, is at hand to release him, by collusion with his gaoler, and places him under the protection of William Longsword.grancUon of Henry IL, and Pair Rosamund, who is on the eve of departure for the Holy Land. The parting of LungaworH with his noble mother at Lacock is pathetically de*cribed,andHilary now embarks with his pro­tector and suite as a soldier of the Cross in the good ship “Nicholas” of 80 tons at Southamp­ton to join St Louis at Damietta, already in

• Th» "Orlflsmm# in Bfypt," I rol. tro. bj VerrtUy ossa Butcbsr, D.D. London i J. M. Dtn, A Co., WAKBwUord fr'W.W.O'FriMfrM, the possession of the King. Hilary is, as yet, u: «ware that his sister Anora, who he believes to lie dead, has left her home trusting her limier to a renegade scoundrel, de Gournay, n»w with her in Egypt under the pseudonym

list.item: r V isr, and that Longsword has sworn to res­cue hor. On landing at Damietta they are in- -1,101 by a rabme horde of Greeks and Cypri-

*e who hail them with every insulting epithet including the monkey insinuation of “tails,” ana with much difficulty make thoir way iuto the presence of King Louis, who welcomes them with unfeigned delight “No celestial vision was ever hailed more gladly than that sight. The English fell on their knees before the cross. The chanters stopped, for Louis himself uttered a ‘non nobis,’ and clasped Longsword to his breast”

div.p: Hilary,-who bore'makes his first acquaint­ance with the “Oriflamme," now wanders in the dusk through a crowd of camp followers, relic sellers, and baksheesh shrieking children to a spot beyond the walls of the city, where he meets the heroine of the romance, the Coptic maiden Dimmna, Who Hilary saves from a worse fate than that which had threatened his “baby” sweetheart at Laoock. The pair take shelter in the crypt of a Coptic “Dcir” from the ruthless savagery of the apostate Nasr, in search of his lost mistress Anora, who had succeeded in escaping from his tyrannous clutches. As is natural and proper, Hilary now falls over head and ears in love with Dimiana and she with him.

Throughout the rest of the story, in whioh the interest and sympathy of the reader for the affianced pair is never allowed to flag, a spirited account of the disasters which befell St, Louis and his devoted band, as described by da Juinville, Matthew Paris, Guillaume de Chartres, Guillaume de Mancis, and other contemporary chroniclers of this short-lived campaign, torms the tree around which the ivy of the love story picturesquely clings. But we must not anticipate the dénouement

The sketch we have outlined of this highly ing and well-told story is all that the space at interest our disposal allows, and we leave it with a warm commendation to the attention of all lovers of historical romance, ending with a quotation from the scene of the fatal Bhrove Tuesday duriug the battle of Man- sura in 1249 A.D.:—

“Longsword s command was lost in a loud wail that drowned the war cries and orders of single knights and captains, in a confused sound of lear and panic. All the hosts, knights, squiresVid jnen-at-arms turned to look at the bank which they- had left, where the King and his chosen men were just desceudiug into the stream before him, in gold armour, rode Sir Johu d’Orleans, bearing the Oriflamme. Ail had seen it a moment before, high and lifted on its staff of gold, flaming like a beacon. Now, by a luckless stumble, the standard- bearer was battling for dear life in the water, and the Oriflamme, for a minute which seemed an hour, was out of sight. A hundred voices cried “Bhame !” A score of men grasped the banner, but it was not raised until its flamelets ot silk and embroidery were drooped and draggled in the water. Sir John clutched at the staff with both hands, and his horse was earned from uudér him by the current His charger’s head, with its spiked iroutlet, showed like a unicorn or some strange monster in the circle of blood and churning water ; then steed and rider sank for ever. The next moment the King had sprung from his steed, and stood on the bank with the rescued Oriflamme in his hand.’’

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. This Company is formed for the purposes set oat in its Memorandum of Assoui ition, and in particular to oonduct business in Egypt and the Soudan, as opportunity affords, and more particnlarly:—'
To purchase, lease, hire and secure concessions of land eithor in town or country.
To reclaim, improve, cultivate, develop, lease, or otherwise deal with Properties when acquired.
To develop building land by the erection of houses or otherwise.
To advance money on mortgage or otherwise, to acquire mortgage or other securities either individually or jointly with others.
To instal irrigation works, supplying the necessary plant for the purpose; to construct canals, drains, roads and tramways, and to carry on industries connected with Agricultural enterprises.
To carry on any business whiob may be profitably or conveniently worked in connection with any of the foregoing enterprises.

Egypt presents a large field for profitable employment of money in lending on safe mortgage. The gross value of land in Egypt is put by expertsat £300,000,000, an average value of £50 per fed dan on 6,000,000 feddans.

The advance in prosperity of the country owing to British Administration, the Anglo-Frenob Agreement, and the recent proposed official introduction of the English language into the Mixed Tribunals is well known. The value of land in Egypt for agricultural and building purposes is shewn by innumerable sales and ro-sales at c instantly enhanced prices, and by the market quotation of Land Companies operating in Egypt, and it is believed that opportunities will occur of securing lana which should greatly increase in valuo within a short space of time

Owing to the increase in the population of the larger towns of Egypt, there is a very healthy and steady demand for well-boilt houses, and in the purchase development and resale ot estates for residential and other purpose, ample soope for remunerative business is afforded; it is considered that from this source the Company sh.iuld derive a fair income.

The opening of Government lands in the Soudan should not oTiTy afford favourable opp irtunity for investing large Capital amounts on mortgage for many years to come, bnt also offer favourable opportunities for purchase and development. The conversion of burin land to ca- nalistd tummer cultivation in Middle Egypt, the regular reclamation and improvement of salt Iona in Lower Egypt offer additional oocasion for profitable business.

The c'imate of Egypt is such, and the richness of the soil is so great, that crops can bo grown continuously, the land not requiring to lie fallow. The land in Lower Bgypt grows a winter crop of beans, wheat, barley, clover, &c., and again a summer crop of cotton, rioe or mmte, besides minor crops of numerous kinds of vegetables. The chief products are ootton, wheat, maize, barley, rice, beans, lentils, peas, rape, lettuoe, mustard, saffron, capsicum, aniseed, sugar cane, figs dates, oranges, lemons, melons, mandarins, limes, &c., &c.
The Articles of Association provide as follows

' As remuneration for his services as a Director, the Chairman shall receive remuneration at the rate of £250 per annum, and the other Directors shall eaph receive remuneration at the rate cf £200 per annum. In addition to the said fix^d remuneration there shall be divided between the Directors in such manner as they Riay determine a sum equal to 10 per bent! on the profits certified by the Auditors of the' Company to have'been made in each year in exoess of a sum sufficient to provide a dividend ot 7 per oeht upon the amount paid up or credited as paid up on the Ordinary Shares for the time being, having regard to the provisions as to the division of profits hereinbefore oontained, but without making any provision for a Reserve Fund. The Directors for the time being may from time to time appoint one or more of their body to bo tho Mauaging Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold soon office, and may from time to time remove or dismiss him or them from office and appoint auother or others in his or their place or places. The remuneration of a Managing Director or a Director or Directors acting as managers shall from time to time be fixed by the Directors, and may be by way of salary or oommission, or participation in profits, or by any or/and all of these modes. If any Director, being willing, shall be called upon to perform extra servioe, or to make any special exertiouB in going or residing abroad, or otherwise, <br any of the purposes of the Company, or act as Trustee for the Company or its DebJutu re Hplders, and shall ao so, the Company may remunerate snob Director, either oy a fixed sum or by a percentage ot profits, or otherwise, as may be determined by the Directors, and suoh remuneration may be either in addition to or in substitution for nis remuneration above provided.

Applications for Sliares should be made on the accompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amount payable on application to the Company's Bankers. If no allotment is made, the Application money will he returned in full, and where the number of Shares allotted is less than that applied for the surplus will be credited in reduction of the amount payable on allotment, and any excess will be returned to tho Applicant.
Failure to j>ay any instalment when due will render the previous payments liable to be forfeited.

A copy of the Memorandum of Ass 'ciation, with names, addresses and descriptions of the Signatories thereof and the number of Shares subscribed for by them respectively will be found in the fold of the Prospectus, of which it forms part.
The minimum subscription upon which the Directors may proceed to Allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at £100,000.

The estimated preliminary expenses of the Company, including registration fees and advertising and issuing this Prospectus in this, oountry and in Egypt, and all other expenses, except brokerage on application for shares, and • Stamps on Share 'Warrants, amount to six thousand pounds; and in relation thereto a Contract dated the 22nd day of Fobruary, 1905. has been made between George Hamilton Craig of the one part, and Sydney William Bartman, as Trustee for the Company^ of the other part, whereby the Companyiagrees to pay six. thousand pounds lor such preliminary oxpenxeu, tho said George Hamilton Craig being entitled to retain any difference between the preli urinary expenses and six thousand pounds, and undertaking to pay any sum by which the estimate shall fall short
A brokerage of Sixpenoe per Share will be paid to Brokers and Bankers on all Shares applied for and alloted to the public on Application Forms hearing their stamps.
Application will be made to the Committee of the London Stock Exchange in due oourse for a settlement and quotation of the Company's Snstws.
Print of die Memorandum and Artiolea of Association of the Company, and oopy of the above-mentioned Contract, can be inspected at the Office of the Solicitors to thS.Company.
